title: The Life of Timon of Athens

scenes.location: Athens. A hall in Timon's house

dialogues.speaker: Poet
dialogues.line: Good day, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Painter
dialogues.line: I am glad you're well.

dialogues.speaker: Poet
dialogues.line: I have not seen you long. How goes the world?

dialogues.speaker: Painter
dialogues.line: It wears, sir, as it grows.

dialogues.speaker: Poet
dialogues.line: Ay, that's well known. But what particular rarity? What strange, Which manifold record not matches? See, Magic of bounty, all these spirits thy power Hath conjured to attend! I know the merchant.

dialogues.speaker: Painter
dialogues.line: I know them both. Th' other's a jeweller.

dialogues.speaker: Merchant
dialogues.line: O, 'tis a worthy lord!

dialogues.speaker: Jeweller
dialogues.line: Nay, that's most fixed.

dialogues.speaker: Merchant
dialogues.line: A most incomparable man, breathed, as it were, To an untirable and continuate goodness. He passes.

dialogues.speaker: Jeweller
dialogues.line: I have a jewel here-

dialogues.speaker: Merchant
dialogues.line: O, pray let's see't. For the Lord Timon, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Jeweller
dialogues.line: If he will touch the estimate. But for that-

dialogues.speaker: Poet
dialogues.line: When we for recompense have praised the vile, It stains the glory in that happy verse Which aptly sings the good.

dialogues.speaker: Merchant
dialogues.line: 'Tis a good form.

dialogues.speaker: Jeweller
dialogues.line: And rich. Here is a water, look ye.

dialogues.speaker: Painter
dialogues.line: You are rapt, sir, in some work, some dedication To the great lord.

dialogues.speaker: Poet
dialogues.line: A thing slipped idly from me. Our poesy is as a gum which oozes From whence 'tis nourished. The fire i' th' flint Shows not till it be struck; our gentle flame Provokes itself and, like the current, flies Each bound it chases. What have you there?

dialogues.speaker: Painter
dialogues.line: A picture, sir. When comes your book forth?

dialogues.speaker: Poet
dialogues.line: Upon the heels of my presentment, sir. Let's see your piece.

dialogues.speaker: Painter
dialogues.line: 'Tis a good piece.

dialogues.speaker: Poet
dialogues.line: So 'tis. This comes off well and excellent.

dialogues.speaker: Painter
dialogues.line: Indifferent.

dialogues.speaker: Poet
dialogues.line: Admirable! How this grace Speaks his own standing! What a mental power This eye shoots forth! How big imagination Moves in this lip! To th' dumbness of the gesture One might interpret.

dialogues.speaker: Painter
dialogues.line: It is a pretty mocking of the life. Here is a touch. Is't good?

dialogues.speaker: Poet
dialogues.line: I'll say of it, It tutors nature. Artificial strife Lives in these touches livelier than life.

dialogues.speaker: Painter
dialogues.line: How this lord is followed!

dialogues.speaker: Poet
dialogues.line: The senators of Athens, happy men!

dialogues.speaker: Painter
dialogues.line: Look, more!

dialogues.speaker: Poet
dialogues.line: You see this confluence, this great flood of visitors. I have in this rough work shaped out a man Whom this beneath world doth embrace and hug With amplest entertainment. My free drift Halts not particularly, but moves itself In a wide sea of wax. No levelled malice Infects one comma in the course I hold, But flies an eagle flight, bold and forth on, Leaving no tract behind.

dialogues.speaker: Painter
dialogues.line: How shall I understand you?

dialogues.speaker: Poet
dialogues.line: I will unbolt to you. You see how all conditions, how all minds, As well of glib and slipp'ry creatures as Of grave and austere quality, tender down Their services to Lord Timon. His large fortune, Upon his good and gracious nature hanging, Subdues and properties to his love and tendance All sorts of hearts; yea, from the glass-faced flatterer To Apemantus, that few things loves better Than to abhor himself; even he drops down The knee before him and returns in peace Most rich in Timon's nod.

dialogues.speaker: Painter
dialogues.line: I saw them speak together.

dialogues.speaker: Poet
dialogues.line: Sir, I have upon a high and pleasant hill Feigned Fortune to be throned. The base o' th' mount Is ranked with all deserts, all kind of natures That labour on the bosom of this sphere To propagate their states. Amongst them all Whose eyes are on this sovereign lady fixed, One do I personate of Lord Timon's frame, Whom Fortune with her ivory hand wafts to her, Whose present grace to present slaves and servants Translates his rivals.

dialogues.speaker: Painter
dialogues.line: 'Tis conceived to scope. This throne, this Fortune, and this hill, methinks, With one man beckoned from the rest below, Bowing his head against the steepy mount To climb his happiness, would be well expressed In our condition.

dialogues.speaker: Poet
dialogues.line: Nay, sir, but hear me on. All those which were his fellows but of late, Some better than his value, on the moment Follow his strides, his lobbies fill with tendance, Rain sacrificial whisperings in his ear, Make sacred even his stirrup, and through him Drink the free air.

dialogues.speaker: Painter
dialogues.line: Ay, marry, what of these?

dialogues.speaker: Poet
dialogues.line: When Fortune in her shift and change of mood Spurns down her late beloved, all his dependants, Which laboured after him to the mountain's top Even on their knees and hands, let him slip down, Not one accompanying his declining foot.

dialogues.speaker: Painter
dialogues.line: 'Tis common. A thousand moral paintings I can show That shall demonstrate these quick blows of Fortune's More pregnantly than words. Yet you do well To show Lord Timon that mean eyes have seen The foot above the head. Trumpets sound. Enter Lord Timon, addressing himself courteously to every suitor. He is accompanied by a Messenger; Lucilius and other servants follow.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Imprisoned is he, say you?

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: Ay, my good lord. Five talents is his debt, His means most short, his creditors most strait. Your honourable letter he desires To those have shut him up, which, failing, Periods his comfort.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Noble Ventidius. Well, I am not of that feather to shake off My friend when he must need me. I do know him A gentleman that well deserves a help, Which he shall have. I'll pay the debt and free him.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: Your lordship ever binds him.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Commend me to him, I will send his ransom; And, being enfranchised, bid him come to me. 'Tis not enough to help the feeble up, But to support him after. Fare you well.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: All happiness to your honour.

dialogues.speaker: Old Athenian
dialogues.line: Lord Timon, hear me speak.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Freely, good father.

dialogues.speaker: Old Athenian
dialogues.line: Thou hast a servant named Lucilius.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: I have so. What of him?

dialogues.speaker: Old Athenian
dialogues.line: Most noble Timon, call the man before thee.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Attends he here or no? Lucilius!

dialogues.speaker: Lucilius
dialogues.line: Here, at your lordship's service.

dialogues.speaker: Old Athenian
dialogues.line: This fellow here, Lord Timon, this thy creature, By night frequents my house. I am a man That from my first have been inclined to thrift, And my estate deserves an heir more raised Than one which holds a trencher.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Well, what further?

dialogues.speaker: Old Athenian
dialogues.line: One only daughter have I, no kin else, On whom I may confer what I have got. The maid is fair, o' th' youngest for a bride, And I have bred her at my dearest cost In qualities of the best. This man of thine Attempts her love. I prithee, noble lord, Join with me to forbid him her resort; Myself have spoke in vain.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: The man is honest.

dialogues.speaker: Old Athenian
dialogues.line: Therefore he will be, Timon. His honesty rewards him in itself; It must not bear my daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Does she love him?

dialogues.speaker: Old Athenian
dialogues.line: She is young and apt. Our own precedent passions do instruct us What levity's in youth.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Love you the maid?

dialogues.speaker: Lucilius
dialogues.line: Ay, my good lord, and she accepts of it.

dialogues.speaker: Old Athenian
dialogues.line: If in her marriage my consent be missing, I call the gods to witness, I will choose Mine heir from forth the beggars of the world And dispossess her all.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: How shall she be endowed, If she be mated with an equal husband?

dialogues.speaker: Old Athenian
dialogues.line: Three talents on the present; in future, all.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: This gentleman of mine hath served me long. To build his fortune I will strain a little, For 'tis a bond in men. Give him thy daughter. What you bestow, in him I'll counterpoise, And make him weigh with her.

dialogues.speaker: Old Athenian
dialogues.line: Most noble lord, Pawn me to this your honour, she is his.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: My hand to thee; mine honour on my promise.

dialogues.speaker: Lucilius
dialogues.line: Humbly I thank your lordship. Never may That state or fortune fall into my keeping Which is not owed to you.

dialogues.speaker: Poet
dialogues.line: Vouchsafe my labour, and long live your lordship.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: I thank you, you shall hear from me anon. Go not away.-What have you there, my friend?

dialogues.speaker: Painter
dialogues.line: A piece of painting, which I do beseech Your lordship to accept.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Painting is welcome. The painting is almost the natural man, For since dishonour traffics with man's nature, He is but outside; these pencilled figures are Even such as they give out. I like your work, And you shall find I like it. Wait attendance Till you hear further from me.

dialogues.speaker: Painter
dialogues.line: The gods preserve you.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Well fare you, gentleman. Give me your hand. We must needs dine together. Sir, your jewel Hath suffered under praise.

dialogues.speaker: Jeweller
dialogues.line: What, my lord, dispraise?

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: A mere satiety of commendations. If I should pay you for 't as 'tis extolled, It would unclew me quite.

dialogues.speaker: Jeweller
dialogues.line: My lord, 'tis rated As those which sell would give. But you well know Things of like value, differing in the owners, Are prized by their masters. Believe't, dear lord, You mend the jewel by the wearing it.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Well mocked.

dialogues.speaker: Merchant
dialogues.line: No, my good lord, he speaks the common tongue, Which all men speak with him.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Look who comes here. Will you be chid?

dialogues.speaker: Jeweller
dialogues.line: We'll bear, with your lordship.

dialogues.speaker: Merchant
dialogues.line: He'll spare none.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Good morrow to thee, gentle Apemantus.

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: Till I be gentle, stay thou for thy good morrow- When thou art Timon's dog, and these knaves honest.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Why dost thou call them knaves? Thou know'st them not.

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: Are they not Athenians?

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: Then I repent not.

dialogues.speaker: Jeweller
dialogues.line: You know me, Apemantus?

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: Thou know'st I do, I called thee by thy name.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Thou art proud, Apemantus.

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: Of nothing so much as that I am not like Timon.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Whither art going?

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: To knock out an honest Athenian's brains.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: That's a deed thou'lt die for.

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: Right, if doing nothing be death by th' law.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: How lik'st thou this picture, Apemantus?

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: The best, for the innocence.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Wrought he not well that painted it?

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: He wrought better that made the painter, and yet he's but a filthy piece of work.

dialogues.speaker: Painter
dialogues.line: You're a dog.

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: Thy mother's of my generation. What's she, if I be a dog?

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Wilt dine with me, Apemantus?

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: No, I eat not lords.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: An thou shouldst, thou'dst anger ladies.

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: O, they eat lords. So they come by great bellies.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: That's a lascivious apprehension.

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: So thou apprehend'st it, take it for thy labour.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: How dost thou like this jewel, Apemantus?

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: Not so well as plain-dealing, which will not cost a man a doit.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: What dost thou think 'tis worth?

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: Not worth my thinking. How now, poet?

dialogues.speaker: Poet
dialogues.line: How now, philosopher?

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: Thou liest.

dialogues.speaker: Poet
dialogues.line: Art not one?

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Poet
dialogues.line: Then I lie not.

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: Art not a poet?

dialogues.speaker: Poet
dialogues.line: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: Then thou liest. Look in thy last work, where thou hast feigned him a worthy fellow.

dialogues.speaker: Poet
dialogues.line: That's not feigned, he is so.

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: Yes, he is worthy of thee, and to pay thee for thy labour. He that loves to be flattered is worthy o' th' flatterer. Heavens, that I were a lord!

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: What wouldst do then, Apemantus?

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: E'en as Apemantus does now, hate a lord with my heart.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: What, thyself?

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: Ay.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Wherefore?

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: That I had no angry wit to be a lord. Art not thou a merchant?

dialogues.speaker: Merchant
dialogues.line: Ay, Apemantus.

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: Traffic confound thee, if the gods will not.

dialogues.speaker: Merchant
dialogues.line: If traffic do it, the gods do it.

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: Traffic's thy god, and thy god confound thee! Trumpet sounds. Enter a Messenger.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: What trumpet's that?

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: 'Tis Alcibiades, and some twenty horse, All of companionship.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Pray entertain them, give them guide to us. You must needs dine with me. Go not you hence Till I have thanked you; when dinner's done, Show me this piece. I am joyful of your sights. Most welcome, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: So, so, there! Aches contract and starve your supple joints! That there should be small love amongst these sweet knaves, And all this courtesy! The strain of man's bred out Into baboon and monkey.

dialogues.speaker: Alcibiades
dialogues.line: Sir, you have saved my longing, and I feed Most hungerly on your sight.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Right welcome, sir! Ere we depart we'll share a bounteous time In different pleasures. Pray you, let us in.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: What time o' day is't, Apemantus?

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: Time to be honest.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: That time serves still.

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: The more accursed thou, that still omitt'st it.

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: Thou art going to Lord Timon's feast?

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: Ay, to see meat fill knaves and wine heat fools.

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: Fare thee well, fare thee well.

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: Thou art a fool to bid me farewell twice.

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: Why, Apemantus?

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: Shouldst have kept one to thyself, for I mean to give thee none.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: Hang thyself!

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: No, I will do nothing at thy bidding. Make thy requests to thy friend.

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: Away, unpeaceable dog, or I'll spurn thee hence.

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: I will fly, like a dog, the heels o' th' ass.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: He's opposite to humanity. Come, shall we in And taste Lord Timon's bounty? He outgoes The very heart of kindness.

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: He pours it out; Plutus, the god of gold, Is but his steward. No meed but he repays Sevenfold above itself, no gift to him But breeds the giver a return exceeding All use of quittance.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: The noblest mind he carries That ever governed man.

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: Long may he live in fortunes. Shall we in?

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: I'll keep you company.

scenes.location: The Same. A room of state in Timon's house

dialogues.speaker: Ventidius
dialogues.line: Most honoured Timon, It hath pleased the gods to remember my father's age And call him to long peace. He is gone happy and has left me rich. Then, as in grateful virtue I am bound To your free heart, I do return those talents, Doubled with thanks and service, from whose help I derived liberty.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: O, by no means, Honest Ventidius. You mistake my love. I gave it freely ever, and there's none Can truly say he gives if he receives. If our betters play at that game, we must not dare To imitate them; faults that are rich are fair.

dialogues.speaker: Ventidius
dialogues.line: A noble spirit!

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Nay, my lords, ceremony was but devised at first To set a gloss on faint deeds, hollow welcomes, Recanting goodness, sorry ere 'tis shown; But where there is true friendship there needs none. Pray, sit, more welcome are ye to my fortunes Than my fortunes to me.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: My lord, we always have confessed it.

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: Ho, ho, confessed it? Hanged it, have you not?

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: O Apemantus, you are welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: No, You shall not make me welcome. I come to have thee thrust me out of doors.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Fie, thou'rt a churl, ye've got a humour there Does not become a man; 'tis much to blame. They say, my lords, _ira furor brevis est_, But yond man is ever angry. Go, let him have a table by himself, For he does neither affect company, Nor is he fit for it indeed.

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: Let me stay at thine apperil, Timon. I come to observe; I give thee warning on't.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: I take no heed of thee. Thou'rt an Athenian, therefore, welcome. I myself would have no power; prithee; let my meat make thee silent.

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: I scorn thy meat, 'twould choke me, for I should ne'er flatter thee. O you gods, what a number of men eats Timon, and he sees 'em not! It grieves me to see so many dip their meat in one man's blood; and all the madness is, he cheers them up too. I wonder men dare trust themselves with men. Methinks they should invite them without knives. Good for their meat, and safer for their lives. There's much example for 't. The fellow that sits next him, now parts bread with him, pledges the breath of him in a divided draft, is the readiest man to kill him. 'T has been proved. If I were a huge man, I should fear to drink at meals, Lest they should spy my wind-pipe's dangerous notes. Great men should drink with harness on their throats.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: My lord, in heart, and let the health go round.

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: Let it flow this way, my good lord.

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: Flow this way? A brave fellow! He keeps his tides well. Those healths will make thee and thy state look ill, Timon. Here's that which is too weak to be a sinner, Honest water, which ne'er left man i' the mire. This and my food are equals, there's no odds. Feasts are too proud to give thanks to the gods. _Apemantus' grace_ Immortal gods, I crave no pelf, I pray for no man but myself. Grant I may never prove so fond To trust man on his oath or bond, Or a harlot for her weeping, Or a dog that seems a-sleeping, Or a keeper with my freedom, Or my friends if I should need 'em. Amen. So fall to't. Rich men sin, and I eat root. Much good dich thy good heart, Apemantus!

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Captain Alcibiades, your heart's in the field now.

dialogues.speaker: Alcibiades
dialogues.line: My heart is ever at your service, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: You had rather be at a breakfast of enemies than a dinner of friends.

dialogues.speaker: Alcibiades
dialogues.line: So they were bleeding new, my lord, there's no meat like 'em. I could wish my best friend at such a feast.

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: Would all those flatterers were thine enemies then, that then thou mightst kill 'em, and bid me to 'em.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: Might we but have that happiness, my lord, that you would once use our hearts, whereby we might express some part of our zeals, we should think ourselves for ever perfect.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: O, no doubt, my good friends, but the gods themselves have provided that I shall have much help from you. How had you been my friends else? Why have you that charitable title from thousands, did not you chiefly belong to my heart? I have told more of you to myself than you can with modesty speak in your own behalf. And thus far I confirm you. O you gods, think I, what need we have any friends if we should ne'er have need of 'em? They were the most needless creatures living, should we ne'er have use for 'em, and would most resemble sweet instruments hung up in cases, that keep their sounds to themselves. Why, I have often wished myself poorer that I might come nearer to you. We are born to do benefits, and what better or properer can we call our own than the riches of our friends? O, what a precious comfort 'tis to have so many, like brothers, commanding one another's fortunes. O joy's e'en made away ere't can be born! Mine eyes cannot hold out water, methinks. To forget their faults, I drink to you.

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: Thou weep'st to make them drink, Timon.

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: Joy had the like conception in our eyes And, at that instant like a babe sprung up.

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: Ho, ho! I laugh to think that babe a bastard.

dialogues.speaker: Third Lord
dialogues.line: I promise you, my lord, you moved me much.

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: Much!

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: What means that trump? How now?

dialogues.speaker: Servant
dialogues.line: Please you, my lord, there are certain ladies most desirous of admittance.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Ladies? What are their wills?

dialogues.speaker: Servant
dialogues.line: There comes with them a forerunner, my lord, which bears that office, to signify their pleasures.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: I pray, let them be admitted.

dialogues.speaker: Cupid
dialogues.line: Hail to thee, worthy Timon, and to all That of his bounties taste! The five best senses Acknowledge thee their patron and come freely To gratulate thy plenteous bosom. There Taste, touch, all, pleased from thy table rise; They only now come but to feast thine eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: They're welcome all, let 'em have kind admittance. Music, make their welcome!

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: You see, my lord, how ample you're beloved. Music. Enter a masque of Ladies as Amazons, with lutes in their hands, dancing and playing.

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: Hoy-day! What a sweep of vanity comes this way. They dance? They are madwomen. Like madness is the glory of this life, As this pomp shows to a little oil and root. We make ourselves fools to disport ourselves, And spend our flatteries to drink those men Upon whose age we void it up again With poisonous spite and envy. Who lives that's not depraved or depraves? Who dies that bears not one spurn to their graves Of their friend's gift? I should fear those that dance before me now Would one day stamp upon me. 'T has been done. Men shut their doors against a setting sun.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: You have done our pleasures much grace, fair ladies, Set a fair fashion on our entertainment, Which was not half so beautiful and kind. You have added worth unto 't and lustre, And entertained me with mine own device. I am to thank you for 't.

dialogues.speaker: First Lady
dialogues.line: My lord, you take us even at the best.

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: Faith, for the worst is filthy and would not hold taking, I doubt me.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Ladies, there is an idle banquet attends you, Please you to dispose yourselves.

dialogues.speaker: All Ladies
dialogues.line: Most thankfully, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Flavius!

dialogues.speaker: Flavius
dialogues.line: My lord?

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: The little casket bring me hither.

dialogues.speaker: Flavius
dialogues.line: Yes, my lord.  More jewels yet? There is no crossing him in 's humour; Else I should tell him well, i' faith, I should, When all's spent, he'd be crossed then, an he could. 'Tis pity bounty had not eyes behind, That man might ne'er be wretched for his mind.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: Where be our men?

dialogues.speaker: Servant
dialogues.line: Here, my lord, in readiness.

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: Our horses!

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: O, my friends, I have one word To say to you. Look you, my good lord, I must entreat you, honour me so much As to advance this jewel. Accept it and wear it, Kind my lord.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: I am so far already in your gifts-

dialogues.speaker: All
dialogues.line: So are we all.

dialogues.speaker: Servant
dialogues.line: My lord, there are certain nobles of the Senate Newly alighted and come to visit you.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: They are fairly welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Flavius
dialogues.line: I beseech your honour, Vouchsafe me a word. It does concern you near.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Near? Why then, another time I'll hear thee. I prithee let's be provided to show them entertainment.

dialogues.speaker: Flavius
dialogues.line: I scarce know how.

dialogues.speaker: Second Servant
dialogues.line: May it please your honour, Lord Lucius, Out of his free love, hath presented to you Four milk-white horses, trapped in silver.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: I shall accept them fairly; let the presents Be worthily entertained. How now? What news?

dialogues.speaker: Third Servant
dialogues.line: Please you, my lord, that honourable gentleman, Lord Lucullus, entreats your company tomorrow to hunt with him and has sent your honour two brace of greyhounds.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: I'll hunt with him; and let them be received, Not without fair reward.

dialogues.speaker: Flavius
dialogues.line: What will this come to? He commands us to provide, and give great gifts, And all out of an empty coffer; Nor will he know his purse or yield me this: To show him what a beggar his heart is, Being of no power to make his wishes good. His promises fly so beyond his state That what he speaks is all in debt; he owes For every word. He is so kind that he now Pays interest for 't; his land's put to their books. Well, would I were gently put out of office Before I were forced out. Happier is he that has no friend to feed Than such that do e'en enemies exceed. I bleed inwardly for my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: You do yourselves much wrong, You bate too much of your own merits. Here, my lord, a trifle of our love.

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: With more than common thanks I will receive it.

dialogues.speaker: Third Lord
dialogues.line: O, he's the very soul of bounty!

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: And now I remember, my lord, you gave good words the other day of a bay courser I rode on. 'Tis yours because you liked it.

dialogues.speaker: Third Lord
dialogues.line: O, I beseech you, pardon me, my lord, in that.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: You may take my word, my lord. I know no man Can justly praise but what he does affect. I weigh my friend's affection with mine own. I'll tell you true, I'll call to you.

dialogues.speaker: All Lords
dialogues.line: O, none so welcome!

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: I take all and your several visitations So kind to heart, 'tis not enough to give; Methinks I could deal kingdoms to my friends, And ne'er be weary. Alcibiades, Thou art a soldier, therefore seldom rich. It comes in charity to thee, for all thy living Is 'mongst the dead, and all the lands thou hast Lie in a pitched field.

dialogues.speaker: Alcibiades
dialogues.line: Ay, defiled land, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: We are so virtuously bound-

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: And so am I to you.

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: So infinitely endeared-

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: All to you. Lights, more lights!

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: The best of happiness, honour, and fortunes keep with you, Lord Timon.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Ready for his friends.

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: What a coil's here! Serving of becks and jutting out of bums! I doubt whether their legs be worth the sums That are given for 'em. Friendship's full of dregs. Methinks false hearts should never have sound legs. Thus honest fools lay out their wealth on curtsies.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Now, Apemantus, if thou wert not sullen, I would be good to thee.

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: No, I'll nothing, for if I should be bribed too, there would be none left to rail upon thee, and then thou wouldst sin the faster. Thou giv'st so long, Timon, I fear me thou wilt give away thyself in paper shortly. What needs these feasts, pomps, and vainglories?

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Nay, an you begin to rail on society once, I am sworn not to give regard to you. Farewell, and come with better music.

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: So. Thou wilt not hear me now, thou shalt not then. I'll lock thy heaven from thee. O, that men's ears should be To counsel deaf, but not to flattery!

scenes.location: Athens. A room in a senator's house

dialogues.speaker: Senator
dialogues.line: And late five thousand. To Varro and to Isidore He owes nine thousand, besides my former sum, Which makes it five-and-twenty. Still in motion Of raging waste! It cannot hold; it will not. If I want gold, steal but a beggar's dog And give it Timon, why, the dog coins gold. If I would sell my horse, and buy twenty more Better than he, why, give my horse to Timon- Ask nothing, give it him-it foals me straight, And able horses. No porter at his gate, But rather one that smiles and still invites All that pass by. It cannot hold; no reason Can sound his state in safety. Caphis, ho! Caphis, I say!

dialogues.speaker: Caphis
dialogues.line: Here, sir, what is your pleasure?

dialogues.speaker: Senator
dialogues.line: Get on your cloak and haste you to Lord Timon. Importune him for my moneys; be not ceased With slight denial, nor then silenced when "Commend me to your master", and the cap Plays in the right hand, thus; but tell him, My uses cry to me, I must serve my turn Out of mine own, his days and times are past, And my reliances on his fracted dates Have smit my credit. I love and honour him, But must not break my back to heal his finger. Immediate are my needs, and my relief Must not be tossed and turned to me in words, But find supply immediate. Get you gone. Put on a most importunate aspect, A visage of demand, for I do fear When every feather sticks in his own wing, Lord Timon will be left a naked gull, Which flashes now a phoenix. Get you gone.

dialogues.speaker: Caphis
dialogues.line: I go, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Senator
dialogues.line: Take the bonds along with you, And have the dates in. Come.

dialogues.speaker: Caphis
dialogues.line: I will, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Senator
dialogues.line: Go.

scenes.location: The same. A hall in Timon's house

dialogues.speaker: Flavius
dialogues.line: No care, no stop, so senseless of expense, That he will neither know how to maintain it Nor cease his flow of riot. Takes no account How things go from him, nor resumes no care Of what is to continue. Never mind Was to be so unwise, to be so kind. What shall be done? He will not hear till feel. I must be round with him, now he comes from hunting. Fie, fie, fie, fie!

dialogues.speaker: Caphis
dialogues.line: Good even, Varro. What, you come for money? VARRO'S SERVANT. Is't not your business too?

dialogues.speaker: Caphis
dialogues.line: It is. And yours too, Isidore? ISIDORE'S SERVANT. It is so.

dialogues.speaker: Caphis
dialogues.line: Would we were all discharged! VARRO'S SERVANT. I fear it.

dialogues.speaker: Caphis
dialogues.line: Here comes the lord.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: So soon as dinner's done, we'll forth again, My Alcibiades. With me? What is your will?

dialogues.speaker: Caphis
dialogues.line: My lord, here is a note of certain dues.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Dues? Whence are you?

dialogues.speaker: Caphis
dialogues.line: Of Athens here, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Go to my steward.

dialogues.speaker: Caphis
dialogues.line: Please it your lordship, he hath put me off To the succession of new days this month. My master is awaked by great occasion To call upon his own and humbly prays you That with your other noble parts you'll suit In giving him his right.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Mine honest friend, I prithee but repair to me next morning.

dialogues.speaker: Caphis
dialogues.line: Nay, good my lord-

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Contain thyself, good friend. VARRO'S SERVANT. One Varro's servant, my good lord- ISIDORE'S SERVANT. From Isidore. He humbly prays your speedy payment.

dialogues.speaker: Caphis
dialogues.line: If you did know, my lord, my master's wants- VARRO'S SERVANT. 'Twas due on forfeiture, my lord, six weeks and past. ISIDORE'S SERVANT. Your steward puts me off, my lord, and I Am sent expressly to your lordship.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Give me breath. I do beseech you, good my lords, keep on, I'll wait upon you instantly.  Come hither. Pray you, How goes the world, that I am thus encountered With clamorous demands of debt, broken bonds, And the detention of long-since-due debts Against my honour?

dialogues.speaker: Flavius
dialogues.line: Please you, gentlemen, The time is unagreeable to this business. Your importunacy cease till after dinner, That I may make his lordship understand Wherefore you are not paid.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Do so, my friends. See them well entertained.

dialogues.speaker: Flavius
dialogues.line: Pray, draw near.

dialogues.speaker: Caphis
dialogues.line: Stay, stay, here comes the fool with Apemantus. Let's ha' some sport with 'em. VARRO'S SERVANT. Hang him, he'll abuse us. ISIDORE'S SERVANT. A plague upon him, dog! VARRO'S SERVANT. How dost, fool?

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: Dost dialogue with thy shadow? VARRO'S SERVANT. I speak not to thee.

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: No, 'tis to thyself.  Come away. ISIDORE'S SERVANT.  There's the fool hangs on your back already.

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: No, thou stand'st single; thou'rt not on him yet.

dialogues.speaker: Caphis
dialogues.line: Where's the fool now?

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: He last asked the question. Poor rogues and usurers' men, bawds between gold and want.

dialogues.speaker: All Servants
dialogues.line: What are we, Apemantus?

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: Asses.

dialogues.speaker: All Servants
dialogues.line: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: That you ask me what you are, and do not know yourselves. Speak to 'em, fool.

dialogues.speaker: Fool
dialogues.line: How do you, gentlemen?

dialogues.speaker: All Servants
dialogues.line: Gramercies, good fool. How does your mistress?

dialogues.speaker: Fool
dialogues.line: She's e'en setting on water to scald such chickens as you are. Would we could see you at Corinth!

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: Good, gramercy.

dialogues.speaker: Fool
dialogues.line: Look you, here comes my mistress' page.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: Why, how now, captain? What do you in this wise company? How dost thou, Apemantus?

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: Would I had a rod in my mouth, that I might answer thee profitably.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: Prithee, Apemantus, read me the superscription of these letters. I know not which is which.

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: Canst not read?

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: No.

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: There will little learning die, then, that day thou art hanged. This is to Lord Timon, this to Alcibiades. Go, thou wast born a bastard, and thou'lt die a bawd.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: Thou wast whelped a dog, and thou shalt famish a dog's death. Answer not; I am gone.

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: E'en so thou outrunn'st grace. Fool, I will go with you to Lord Timon's.

dialogues.speaker: Fool
dialogues.line: Will you leave me there?

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: If Timon stay at home.-You three serve three usurers?

dialogues.speaker: All Servants
dialogues.line: Ay, would they served us!

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: So would I-as good a trick as ever hangman served thief.

dialogues.speaker: Fool
dialogues.line: Are you three usurers' men?

dialogues.speaker: All Servants
dialogues.line: Ay, fool.

dialogues.speaker: Fool
dialogues.line: I think no usurer but has a fool to his servant. My mistress is one, and I am her fool. When men come to borrow of your masters, they approach sadly and go away merry, but they enter my mistress's house merrily and go away sadly. The reason of this? VARRO'S SERVANT. I could render one.

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: Do it then, that we may account thee a whoremaster and a knave, which notwithstanding, thou shalt be no less esteemed. VARRO'S SERVANT. What is a whoremaster, fool?

dialogues.speaker: Fool
dialogues.line: A fool in good clothes, and something like thee. 'Tis a spirit; sometime 't appears like a lord, sometime like a lawyer, sometime like a philosopher, with two stones more than's artificial one. He is very often like a knight; and generally, in all shapes that man goes up and down in from fourscore to thirteen, this spirit walks in. VARRO'S SERVANT. Thou art not altogether a fool.

dialogues.speaker: Fool
dialogues.line: Nor thou altogether a wise man. As much foolery as I have, so much wit thou lack'st.

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: That answer might have become Apemantus. VARRO'S SERVANT. Aside, aside, here comes Lord Timon.

dialogues.speaker: Apemantus
dialogues.line: Come with me, fool, come.

dialogues.speaker: Fool
dialogues.line: I do not always follow lover, elder brother, and woman; sometime the philosopher.

dialogues.speaker: Flavius
dialogues.line: Pray you walk near. I'll speak with you anon.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: You make me marvel wherefore ere this time Had you not fully laid my state before me, That I might so have rated my expense As I had leave of means.

dialogues.speaker: Flavius
dialogues.line: You would not hear me, At many leisures I proposed.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Go to. Perchance some single vantages you took When my indisposition put you back, And that unaptness made your minister Thus to excuse yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Flavius
dialogues.line: O my good lord, At many times I brought in my accounts, Laid them before you; you would throw them off And say you found them in mine honesty. When for some trifling present you have bid me Return so much, I have shook my head and wept, Yea, 'gainst th' authority of manners, prayed you To hold your hand more close. I did endure Not seldom nor no slight checks, when I have Prompted you in the ebb of your estate And your great flow of debts. My loved lord, Though you hear now, too late, yet now's a time. The greatest of your having lacks a half To pay your present debts.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Let all my land be sold.

dialogues.speaker: Flavius
dialogues.line: 'Tis all engaged, some forfeited and gone, And what remains will hardly stop the mouth Of present dues; the future comes apace. What shall defend the interim? And at length How goes our reckoning?

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: To Lacedaemon did my land extend.

dialogues.speaker: Flavius
dialogues.line: O my good lord, the world is but a word; Were it all yours to give it in a breath, How quickly were it gone!

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: You tell me true.

dialogues.speaker: Flavius
dialogues.line: If you suspect my husbandry or falsehood, Call me before th' exactest auditors And set me on the proof. So the gods bless me, When all our offices have been oppressed With riotous feeders, when our vaults have wept With drunken spilth of wine, when every room Hath blazed with lights and brayed with minstrelsy, I have retired me to a wasteful cock And set mine eyes at flow.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Prithee, no more.

dialogues.speaker: Flavius
dialogues.line: Heavens, have I said, the bounty of this lord! How many prodigal bits have slaves and peasants This night englutted? Who is not Timon's? What heart, head, sword, force, means, but is Lord Timon's? Great Timon, noble, worthy, royal Timon! Ah, when the means are gone that buy this praise, The breath is gone whereof this praise is made. Feast-won, fast-lost; one cloud of winter showers, These flies are couched.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Come, sermon me no further. No villainous bounty yet hath passed my heart; Unwisely, not ignobly, have I given. Why dost thou weep? Canst thou the conscience lack To think I shall lack friends? Secure thy heart. If I would broach the vessels of my love And try the argument of hearts by borrowing, Men and men's fortunes could I frankly use As I can bid thee speak.

dialogues.speaker: Flavius
dialogues.line: Assurance bless your thoughts!

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: And in some sort these wants of mine are crowned, That I account them blessings. For by these Shall I try friends. You shall perceive how you Mistake my fortunes. I am wealthy in my friends. Within there! Flaminius! Servilius!

dialogues.speaker: Servants
dialogues.line: My lord, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: I will dispatch you severally.  You to Lord Lucius;  to Lord Lucullus you, I hunted with his honour today;  you to Sempronius. Commend me to their loves; and I am proud, say, that my occasions have found time to use 'em toward a supply of money. Let the request be fifty talents.

dialogues.speaker: Flaminius
dialogues.line: As you have said, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Flavius
dialogues.line: Lord Lucius and Lucullus? Humh!

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Go you, sir, to the senators, Of whom, even to the state's best health, I have Deserved this hearing, Bid 'em send o' th' instant A thousand talents to me.

dialogues.speaker: Flavius
dialogues.line: I have been bold- For that I knew it the most general way- To them to use your signet and your name, But they do shake their heads, and I am here No richer in return.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Is't true? Can't be?

dialogues.speaker: Flavius
dialogues.line: They answer in a joint and corporate voice That now they are at fall, want treasure, cannot Do what they would, are sorry. You are honourable, But yet they could have wished-they know not- Something hath been amiss-a noble nature May catch a wrench-would all were well-'tis pity. And so, intending other serious matters, After distasteful looks and these hard fractions, With certain half-caps and cold-moving nods They froze me into silence.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: You gods, reward them! Prithee, man, look cheerly. These old fellows Have their ingratitude in them hereditary. Their blood is caked, 'tis cold, it seldom flows; 'Tis lack of kindly warmth they are not kind; And nature, as it grows again toward earth, Is fashioned for the journey, dull and heavy. Go to Ventidius. Prithee, be not sad, Thou art true and honest, ingenuously I speak, No blame belongs to thee. Ventidius lately Buried his father, by whose death he's stepped Into a great estate. When he was poor, Imprisoned and in scarcity of friends, I cleared him with five talents. Greet him from me, Bid him suppose some good necessity Touches his friend, which craves to be remembered With those five talents. That had, give't these fellows To whom 'tis instant due. Ne'er speak, or think That Timon's fortunes 'mong his friends can sink.

dialogues.speaker: Flavius
dialogues.line: I would I could not think it. That thought is bounty's foe; Being free itself, it thinks all others so.

scenes.location: Athens. A room in Lucullus' house

dialogues.speaker: Servant
dialogues.line: I have told my lord of you; he is coming down to you.

dialogues.speaker: Flaminius
dialogues.line: I thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Servant
dialogues.line: Here's my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Lucullus
dialogues.line: One of Lord Timon's men? A gift, I warrant. Why, this hits right. I dreamt of a silver basin and ewer tonight.-Flaminius, honest Flaminius, you are very respectively welcome, sir. Fill me some wine. And how does that honourable, complete, free-hearted gentleman of Athens, thy very bountiful good lord and master?

dialogues.speaker: Flaminius
dialogues.line: His health is well, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Lucullus
dialogues.line: I am right glad that his health is well, sir. And what hast thou there under thy cloak, pretty Flaminius?

dialogues.speaker: Flaminius
dialogues.line: Faith, nothing but an empty box, sir, which in my lord's behalf I come to entreat your honour to supply; who, having great and instant occasion to use fifty talents, hath sent to your lordship to furnish him, nothing doubting your present assistance therein.

dialogues.speaker: Lucullus
dialogues.line: La, la, la, la! Nothing doubting, says he? Alas, good lord! A noble gentleman 'tis, if he would not keep so good a house. Many a time and often I ha' dined with him, and told him on't, and come again to supper to him of purpose to have him spend less, and yet he would embrace no counsel, take no warning by my coming. Every man has his fault, and honesty is his. I ha' told him on't, but I could ne'er get him from 't.

dialogues.speaker: Servant
dialogues.line: Please your lordship, here is the wine.

dialogues.speaker: Lucullus
dialogues.line: Flaminius, I have noted thee always wise. Here's to thee.

dialogues.speaker: Flaminius
dialogues.line: Your lordship speaks your pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Lucullus
dialogues.line: I have observed thee always for a towardly prompt spirit, give thee thy due, and one that knows what belongs to reason, and canst use the time well, if the time use thee well. Good parts in thee.  Get you gone, sirrah.- Draw nearer, honest Flaminius. Thy lord's a bountiful gentleman, but thou art wise and thou know'st well enough, although thou com'st to me, that this is no time to lend money, especially upon bare friendship without security. Here's three solidares for thee. Good boy, wink at me, and say thou saw'st me not. Fare thee well.

dialogues.speaker: Flaminius
dialogues.line: Is't possible the world should so much differ, And we alive that lived? Fly, damned baseness, To him that worships thee.

dialogues.speaker: Lucullus
dialogues.line: Ha! Now I see thou art a fool and fit for thy master.

dialogues.speaker: Flaminius
dialogues.line: May these add to the number that may scald thee! Let molten coin be thy damnation, Thou disease of a friend, and not himself! Has friendship such a faint and milky heart It turns in less than two nights? O you gods, I feel my master's passion. This slave Unto his honour has my lord's meat in him. Why should it thrive and turn to nutriment When he is turned to poison? O, may diseases only work upon't, And when he's sick to death, let not that part of nature Which my lord paid for be of any power To expel sickness, but prolong his hour.

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: Who, the Lord Timon? He is my very good friend and an honourable gentleman.

dialogues.speaker: First Stranger
dialogues.line: We know him for no less, though we are but strangers to him. But I can tell you one thing, my lord, and which I hear from common rumours: now Lord Timon's happy hours are done and past, and his estate shrinks from him.

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: Fie, no, do not believe it; he cannot want for money.

dialogues.speaker: Second Stranger
dialogues.line: But believe you this, my lord, that, not long ago one of his men was with the Lord Lucullus to borrow so many talents, nay, urged extremely for't, and showed what necessity belonged to't, and yet was denied.

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: How?

dialogues.speaker: Second Stranger
dialogues.line: I tell you, denied, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: What a strange case was that! Now, before the gods, I am ashamed on't. Denied that honourable man? There was very little honour showed in't. For my own part, I must needs confess, I have received some small kindnesses from him, as money, plate, jewels, and such like trifles, nothing comparing to his; yet had he mistook him, and sent to me, I should ne'er have denied his occasion so many talents.

dialogues.speaker: Servilius
dialogues.line: See, by good hap, yonder's my lord; I have sweat to see his honour.  My honoured lord!

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: Servilius? You are kindly met, sir. Fare thee well. Commend me to thy honourable virtuous lord, my very exquisite friend.

dialogues.speaker: Servilius
dialogues.line: May it please your honour, my lord hath sent-

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: Ha! What has he sent? I am so much endeared to that lord; he's ever sending. How shall I thank him, thinkest thou? And what has he sent now?

dialogues.speaker: Servilius
dialogues.line: Has only sent his present occasion now, my lord, requesting your lordship to supply his instant use with so many talents.

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: I know his lordship is but merry with me; He cannot want fifty-five hundred talents.

dialogues.speaker: Servilius
dialogues.line: But in the meantime he wants less, my lord. If his occasion were not virtuous, I should not urge it half so faithfully.

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: Dost thou speak seriously, Servilius?

dialogues.speaker: Servilius
dialogues.line: Upon my soul, 'tis true, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: What a wicked beast was I to disfurnish myself against such a good time, when I might ha' shown myself honourable! How unluckily it happened that I should purchase the day before for a little part, and undo a great deal of honour! Servilius, now before the gods, I am not able to do-the more beast, I say-I was sending to use Lord Timon myself, these gentlemen can witness; but I would not for the wealth of Athens I had done it now. Commend me bountifully to his good lordship, and I hope his honour will conceive the fairest of me, because I have no power to be kind. And tell him this from me: I count it one of my greatest afflictions, say, that I cannot pleasure such an honourable gentleman. Good Servilius, will you befriend me so far as to use mine own words to him?

dialogues.speaker: Servilius
dialogues.line: Yes, sir, I shall.

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: I'll look you out a good turn, Servilius. True, as you said, Timon is shrunk indeed, And he that's once denied will hardly speed.

dialogues.speaker: First Stranger
dialogues.line: Do you observe this, Hostilius?

dialogues.speaker: Second Stranger
dialogues.line: Ay, too well.

dialogues.speaker: First Stranger
dialogues.line: Why, this is the world's soul, and just of the same piece Is every flatterer's spirit. Who can call him his friend That dips in the same dish? For, in my knowing, Timon has been this lord's father And kept his credit with his purse, Supported his estate, nay, Timon's money Has paid his men their wages. He ne'er drinks But Timon's silver treads upon his lip, And yet-O, see the monstrousness of man When he looks out in an ungrateful shape- He does deny him, in respect of his, What charitable men afford to beggars.

dialogues.speaker: Third Stranger
dialogues.line: Religion groans at it.

dialogues.speaker: First Stranger
dialogues.line: For mine own part, I never tasted Timon in my life, Nor came any of his bounties over me To mark me for his friend. Yet I protest, For his right noble mind, illustrious virtue, And honourable carriage, Had his necessity made use of me, I would have put my wealth into donation, And the best half should have returned to him, So much I love his heart. But I perceive Men must learn now with pity to dispense, For policy sits above conscience.

scenes.location: The same. A room in Sempronius' house

dialogues.speaker: Sempronius
dialogues.line: Must he needs trouble me in't? Hum! 'Bove all others? He might have tried Lord Lucius or Lucullus; And now Ventidius is wealthy too, Whom he redeemed from prison. All these Owe their estates unto him.

dialogues.speaker: Servant
dialogues.line: My lord, They have all been touched and found base metal, For they have all denied him.

dialogues.speaker: Sempronius
dialogues.line: How? Have they denied him? Has Ventidius and Lucullus denied him And does he send to me? Three? Humh! It shows but little love or judgment in him. Must I be his last refuge? His friends, like physicians, Thrive, give him over. Must I take th' cure upon me? Has much disgraced me in't. I'm angry at him, That might have known my place. I see no sense for't But his occasions might have wooed me first; For, in my conscience, I was the first man That e'er received gift from him. And does he think so backwardly of me now That I'll requite it last? No. So it may prove an argument of laughter To th' rest, and I 'mongst lords be thought a fool. I'd rather than the worth of thrice the sum Had sent to me first, but for my mind's sake; I'd such a courage to do him good. But now return, And with their faint reply this answer join: Who bates mine honour shall not know my coin.

dialogues.speaker: Servant
dialogues.line: Excellent! Your lordship's a goodly villain. The devil knew not what he did when he made man politic; he crossed himself by't, and I cannot think but, in the end the villainies of man will set him clear. How fairly this lord strives to appear foul! Takes virtuous copies to be wicked, like those that under hot ardent zeal would set whole realms on fire. Of such a nature is his politic love. This was my lord's best hope, now all are fled Save only the gods. Now his friends are dead, Doors that were ne'er acquainted with their wards Many a bounteous year must be employed Now to guard sure their master. And this is all a liberal course allows, Who cannot keep his wealth must keep his house.

dialogues.speaker: Titus
dialogues.line: The like to you, kind Varro.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensius
dialogues.line: Lucius! What, do we meet together?

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: Ay, and I think One business does command us all; For mine is money.

dialogues.speaker: Titus
dialogues.line: So is theirs and ours.

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: And, sir, Philotus too!

dialogues.speaker: Philotus
dialogues.line: Good day at once.

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: Welcome, good brother. What do you think the hour?

dialogues.speaker: Philotus
dialogues.line: Labouring for nine.

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: So much?

dialogues.speaker: Philotus
dialogues.line: Is not my lord seen yet?

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: Philotus
dialogues.line: I wonder on't, he was wont to shine at seven.

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: Ay, but the days are waxed shorter with him. You must consider that a prodigal course Is like the sun's, but not like his recoverable. I fear 'tis deepest winter in Lord Timon's purse: That is, one may reach deep enough, and yet Find little.

dialogues.speaker: Philotus
dialogues.line: I am of your fear for that.

dialogues.speaker: Titus
dialogues.line: I'll show you how t' observe a strange event. Your lord sends now for money?

dialogues.speaker: Hortensius
dialogues.line: Most true, he does.

dialogues.speaker: Titus
dialogues.line: And he wears jewels now of Timon's gift, For which I wait for money.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensius
dialogues.line: It is against my heart.

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: Mark how strange it shows, Timon in this should pay more than he owes, And e'en as if your lord should wear rich jewels And send for money for 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensius
dialogues.line: I'm weary of this charge, the gods can witness. I know my lord hath spent of Timon's wealth, And now ingratitude makes it worse than stealth. FIRST VARRO'S SERVANT. Yes, mine's three thousand crowns. What's yours?

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: Five thousand mine. FIRST VARRO'S SERVANT. 'Tis much deep, and it should seem by th' sum Your master's confidence was above mine, Else surely his had equalled.

dialogues.speaker: Titus
dialogues.line: One of Lord Timon's men.

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: Flaminius? Sir, a word. Pray, is my lord ready to come forth?

dialogues.speaker: Flaminius
dialogues.line: No, indeed he is not.

dialogues.speaker: Titus
dialogues.line: We attend his lordship; pray, signify so much.

dialogues.speaker: Flaminius
dialogues.line: I need not tell him that, he knows you are too diligent.

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: Ha, is not that his steward muffled so? He goes away in a cloud. Call him, call him.

dialogues.speaker: Titus
dialogues.line: Do you hear, sir? SECOND VARRO'S SERVANT. By your leave, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Flavius
dialogues.line: What do you ask of me, my friend?

dialogues.speaker: Titus
dialogues.line: We wait for certain money here, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Flavius
dialogues.line: Ay, If money were as certain as your waiting, 'Twere sure enough. Why then preferred you not your sums and bills When your false masters eat of my lord's meat? Then they could smile and fawn upon his debts, And take down th' interest into their gluttonous maws. You do yourselves but wrong to stir me up, Let me pass quietly. Believe't, my lord and I have made an end, I have no more to reckon, he to spend.

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: Ay, but this answer will not serve.

dialogues.speaker: Flavius
dialogues.line: If 'twill not serve, 'tis not so base as you, For you serve knaves. FIRST VARRO'S SERVANT. How? What does his cashiered worship mutter? SECOND VARRO'S SERVANT. No matter what, he's poor, and that's revenge enough. Who can speak broader than he that has no house to put his head in? Such may rail against great buildings.

dialogues.speaker: Titus
dialogues.line: O, here's Servilius; now we shall know some answer.

dialogues.speaker: Servilius
dialogues.line: If I might beseech you, gentlemen, to repair some other hour, I should derive much from't. For take't of my soul, my lord leans wondrously to discontent. His comfortable temper has forsook him, he's much out of health and keeps his chamber.

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: Many do keep their chambers are not sick. And if it be so far beyond his health, Methinks he should the sooner pay his debts And make a clear way to the gods.

dialogues.speaker: Servilius
dialogues.line: Good gods!

dialogues.speaker: Titus
dialogues.line: We cannot take this for answer, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Flaminius
dialogues.line: Servilius, help! My lord, my lord!

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: What, are my doors opposed against my passage? Have I been ever free, and must my house Be my retentive enemy, my jail? The place which I have feasted, does it now, Like all mankind, show me an iron heart?

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: Put in now, Titus.

dialogues.speaker: Titus
dialogues.line: My lord, here is my bill.

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: Here's mine.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensius
dialogues.line: And mine, my lord. BOTH VARRO'S SERVANTS. And ours, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Philotus
dialogues.line: All our bills.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Knock me down with 'em! Cleave me to the girdle.

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: Alas, my lord-

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Cut my heart in sums!

dialogues.speaker: Titus
dialogues.line: Mine, fifty talents.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Tell out my blood.

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: Five thousand crowns, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Five thousand drops pays that. What yours, and yours? FIRST VARRO'S SERVANT. My lord- SECOND VARRO'S SERVANT. My lord-

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Tear me, take me, and the gods fall upon you!

dialogues.speaker: Hortensius
dialogues.line: Faith, I perceive our masters may throw their caps at their money. These debts may well be called desperate ones, for a madman owes 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: They have e'en put my breath from me, the slaves. Creditors? Devils!

dialogues.speaker: Flavius
dialogues.line: My dear lord-

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: What if it should be so?

dialogues.speaker: Flavius
dialogues.line: My lord-

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: I'll have it so.-My steward!

dialogues.speaker: Flavius
dialogues.line: Here, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: So fitly? Go, bid all my friends again, Lucius, Lucullus, and Sempronius, all. I'll once more feast the rascals.

dialogues.speaker: Flavius
dialogues.line: O my lord, You only speak from your distracted soul; There is not so much left to furnish out A moderate table.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Be it not in thy care. Go, I charge thee, invite them all. Let in the tide Of knaves once more. My cook and I'll provide.

dialogues.speaker: First Senator
dialogues.line: My lord, you have my voice to 't. The fault's Bloody. 'Tis necessary he should die. Nothing emboldens sin so much as mercy.

dialogues.speaker: Second Senator
dialogues.line: Most true, the law shall bruise 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Alcibiades
dialogues.line: Honour, health, and compassion to the senate!

dialogues.speaker: First Senator
dialogues.line: Now, captain?

dialogues.speaker: Alcibiades
dialogues.line: I am a humble suitor to your virtues, For pity is the virtue of the law, And none but tyrants use it cruelly. It pleases time and fortune to lie heavy Upon a friend of mine, who in hot blood Hath stepped into the law, which is past depth To those that without heed do plunge into't. He is a man, setting his fate aside, Of comely virtues, Nor did he soil the fact with cowardice- An honour in him which buys out his fault- But with a noble fury and fair spirit, Seeing his reputation touched to death, He did oppose his foe; And with such sober and unnoted passion He did behave his anger, ere 'twas spent, As if he had but proved an argument.

dialogues.speaker: First Senator
dialogues.line: You undergo too strict a paradox, Striving to make an ugly deed look fair. Your words have took such pains as if they laboured To bring manslaughter into form and set quarrelling Upon the head of valour, which indeed Is valour misbegot and came into the world When sects and factions were newly born. He's truly valiant that can wisely suffer The worst that man can breathe, and make his wrongs His outsides to wear them like his raiment, carelessly, And ne'er prefer his injuries to his heart, To bring it into danger. If wrongs be evils and enforce us kill, What folly 'tis to hazard life for ill!

dialogues.speaker: Alcibiades
dialogues.line: My lord-

dialogues.speaker: First Senator
dialogues.line: You cannot make gross sins look clear. To revenge is no valour, but to bear.

dialogues.speaker: Alcibiades
dialogues.line: My lords, then, under favour, pardon me If I speak like a captain. Why do fond men expose themselves to battle And not endure all threats? Sleep upon't, And let the foes quietly cut their throats Without repugnancy? If there be Such valour in the bearing, what make we Abroad? Why, then, women are more valiant That stay at home, if bearing carry it, And the ass more captain than the lion, the felon Loaden with irons wiser than the judge, If wisdom be in suffering. O my lords, As you are great, be pitifully good. Who cannot condemn rashness in cold blood? To kill, I grant, is sin's extremest gust, But in defence, by mercy, 'tis most just. To be in anger is impiety, But who is man that is not angry? Weigh but the crime with this.

dialogues.speaker: Second Senator
dialogues.line: You breathe in vain.

dialogues.speaker: Alcibiades
dialogues.line: In vain? His service done At Lacedaemon and Byzantium Were a sufficient briber for his life.

dialogues.speaker: First Senator
dialogues.line: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Alcibiades
dialogues.line: Why, I say, my lords, has done fair service And slain in fight many of your enemies. How full of valour did he bear himself In the last conflict, and made plenteous wounds!

dialogues.speaker: Second Senator
dialogues.line: He has made too much plenty with 'em. He's a sworn rioter. He has a sin That often drowns him and takes his valour prisoner. If there were no foes, that were enough To overcome him. In that beastly fury, He has been known to commit outrages And cherish factions. 'Tis inferred to us His days are foul and his drink dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: First Senator
dialogues.line: He dies.

dialogues.speaker: Alcibiades
dialogues.line: Hard fate! He might have died in war. My lords, if not for any parts in him, Though his right arm might purchase his own time And be in debt to none, yet, more to move you, Take my deserts to his and join 'em both. And, for I know your reverend ages love Security, I'll pawn my victories, all My honour, to you upon his good returns. If by this crime he owes the law his life, Why, let the war receive't in valiant gore, For law is strict, and war is nothing more.

dialogues.speaker: First Senator
dialogues.line: We are for law. He dies. Urge it no more, On height of our displeasure. Friend or brother, He forfeits his own blood that spills another.

dialogues.speaker: Alcibiades
dialogues.line: Must it be so? It must not be. My lords, I do beseech you, know me.

dialogues.speaker: Second Senator
dialogues.line: How?

dialogues.speaker: Alcibiades
dialogues.line: Call me to your remembrances.

dialogues.speaker: Third Senator
dialogues.line: What?

dialogues.speaker: Alcibiades
dialogues.line: I cannot think but your age has forgot me, It could not else be I should prove so base To sue and be denied such common grace. My wounds ache at you.

dialogues.speaker: First Senator
dialogues.line: Do you dare our anger? 'Tis in few words, but spacious in effect: We banish thee for ever.

dialogues.speaker: Alcibiades
dialogues.line: Banish me? Banish your dotage, banish usury, That makes the Senate ugly.

dialogues.speaker: First Senator
dialogues.line: If, after two days' shine, Athens contain thee, Attend our weightier judgment. And, not to swell our spirit, He shall be executed presently.

dialogues.speaker: Alcibiades
dialogues.line: Now the gods keep you old enough, that you may live Only in bone, that none may look on you! I'm worse than mad. I have kept back their foes While they have told their money and let out Their coin upon large interest, I myself Rich only in large hurts. All those for this? Is this the balsam that the usuring senate Pours into captains' wounds? Banishment. It comes not ill. I hate not to be banished. It is a cause worthy my spleen and fury, That I may strike at Athens. I'll cheer up My discontented troops and lay for hearts. 'Tis honour with most lands to be at odds. Soldiers should brook as little wrongs as gods.

scenes.location: A room of state in Timon's house

dialogues.speaker: First Friend
dialogues.line: The good time of day to you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Second Friend
dialogues.line: I also wish it to you. I think this honourable lord did but try us this other day.

dialogues.speaker: First Friend
dialogues.line: Upon that were my thoughts tiring when we encountered. I hope it is not so low with him as he made it seem in the trial of his several friends.

dialogues.speaker: Second Friend
dialogues.line: It should not be, by the persuasion of his new feasting.

dialogues.speaker: First Friend
dialogues.line: I should think so. He hath sent me an earnest inviting, which many my near occasions did urge me to put off; but he hath conjured me beyond them, and I must needs appear.

dialogues.speaker: Second Friend
dialogues.line: In like manner was I in debt to my importunate business, but he would not hear my excuse. I am sorry, when he sent to borrow of me, that my provision was out.

dialogues.speaker: First Friend
dialogues.line: I am sick of that grief too, as I understand how all things go.

dialogues.speaker: Second Friend
dialogues.line: Every man here's so. What would he have borrowed you?

dialogues.speaker: First Friend
dialogues.line: A thousand pieces.

dialogues.speaker: Second Friend
dialogues.line: A thousand pieces!

dialogues.speaker: First Friend
dialogues.line: What of you?

dialogues.speaker: Second Friend
dialogues.line: He sent to me, sir-here he comes.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: With all my heart, gentlemen both! And how fare you?

dialogues.speaker: First Friend
dialogues.line: Ever at the best, hearing well of your lordship.

dialogues.speaker: Second Friend
dialogues.line: The swallow follows not summer more willing than we your lordship.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Nor more willingly leaves winter, such summer birds are men. Gentlemen, our dinner will not recompense this long stay. Feast your ears with the music awhile, if they will fare so harshly o' th' trumpet's sound; we shall to't presently.

dialogues.speaker: First Friend
dialogues.line: I hope it remains not unkindly with your lordship that I returned you an empty messenger.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: O, sir, let it not trouble you.

dialogues.speaker: Second Friend
dialogues.line: My noble lord-

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Ah, my good friend, what cheer?

dialogues.speaker: Second Friend
dialogues.line: My most honourable lord, I am e'en sick of shame that when your lordship this other day sent to me I was so unfortunate a beggar.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Think not on't, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Second Friend
dialogues.line: If you had sent but two hours before-

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Let it not cumber your better remembrance. Come, bring in all together.

dialogues.speaker: Second Friend
dialogues.line: All covered dishes!

dialogues.speaker: First Friend
dialogues.line: Royal cheer, I warrant you.

dialogues.speaker: Third Friend
dialogues.line: Doubt not that, if money and the season can yield it.

dialogues.speaker: First Friend
dialogues.line: How do you? What's the news?

dialogues.speaker: Third Friend
dialogues.line: Alcibiades is banished. Hear you of it?

dialogues.speaker: First And Second Friends
dialogues.line: Alcibiades banished?

dialogues.speaker: Third Friend
dialogues.line: 'Tis so, be sure of it.

dialogues.speaker: First Friend
dialogues.line: How, how?

dialogues.speaker: Second Friend
dialogues.line: I pray you, upon what?

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: My worthy friends, will you draw near?

dialogues.speaker: Third Friend
dialogues.line: I'll tell you more anon. Here's a noble feast toward.

dialogues.speaker: Second Friend
dialogues.line: This is the old man still.

dialogues.speaker: Third Friend
dialogues.line: Will't hold, will't hold?

dialogues.speaker: Second Friend
dialogues.line: It does, but time will-and so-

dialogues.speaker: Third Friend
dialogues.line: I do conceive.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Each man to his stool with that spur as he would to the lip of his mistress. Your diet shall be in all places alike. Make not a city feast of it, to let the meat cool ere we can agree upon the first place. Sit, sit. The gods require our thanks: You great benefactors, sprinkle our society with thankfulness. For your own gifts make yourselves praised, but reserve still to give, lest your deities be despised. Lend to each man enough, that one need not lend to another; for, were your godheads to borrow of men, men would forsake the gods. Make the meat be beloved more than the man that gives it. Let no assembly of twenty be without a score of villains. If there sit twelve women at the table, let a dozen of them be as they are. The rest of your foes, O gods, the senators of Athens, together with the common lag of people, what is amiss in them, you gods, make suitable for destruction. For these my present friends, as they are to me nothing, so in nothing bless them, and to nothing are they welcome. Uncover, dogs, and lap.

dialogues.speaker: Some Speak
dialogues.line: What does his lordship mean?

dialogues.speaker: Some Other
dialogues.line: I know not.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: May you a better feast never behold, You knot of mouth-friends! Smoke and lukewarm water Is your perfection. This is Timon's last, Who, stuck and spangled with your flatteries, Washes it off and sprinkles in your faces Your reeking villainy. Live loathed, and long, Most smiling, smooth, detested parasites, Courteous destroyers, affable wolves, meek bears, You fools of fortune, trencher-friends, time's flies, Cap-and-knee slaves, vapours, and minute-jacks! Of man and beast the infinite malady Crust you quite o'er!  What, dost thou go? Soft! Take thy physic first; thou too, and thou! Stay, I will lend thee money, borrow none. What, all in motion? Henceforth be no feast Whereat a villain's not a welcome guest. Burn, house! Sink Athens! Henceforth hated be Of Timon man and all humanity! Enter Timon's Friends, the Senators with other Lords.

dialogues.speaker: First Friend
dialogues.line: How now, my lords?

dialogues.speaker: Second Friend
dialogues.line: Know you the quality of Lord Timon's fury?

dialogues.speaker: Third Friend
dialogues.line: Push! Did you see my cap?

dialogues.speaker: Fourth Friend
dialogues.line: I have lost my gown.

dialogues.speaker: First Friend
dialogues.line: He's but a mad lord, and nought but humours sways him. He gave me a jewel th' other day, and now he has beat it out of my hat. Did you see my jewel?

dialogues.speaker: Third Friend
dialogues.line: Did you see my cap?

dialogues.speaker: Second Friend
dialogues.line: Here 'tis.

dialogues.speaker: Fourth Friend
dialogues.line: Here lies my gown.

dialogues.speaker: First Friend
dialogues.line: Let's make no stay.

dialogues.speaker: Second Friend
dialogues.line: Lord Timon's mad.

dialogues.speaker: Third Friend
dialogues.line: I feel't upon my bones.

dialogues.speaker: Fourth Friend
dialogues.line: One day he gives us diamonds, next day stones.

dialogues.speaker: Timon
dialogues.line: Let me look back upon thee. O thou wall That girdles in those wolves, dive in the earth And fence not Athens! Matrons, turn incontinent! Obedience fail in children! Slaves and fools, Pluck the grave wrinkled senate from the bench And minister in their steads! To general filths Convert, o' th' instant, green virginity, Do't in your parents' eyes! Bankrupts, hold fast; Rather than render back, out with your knives And cut your trusters' throats! Bound servants, steal! Large-handed robbers your grave masters are, And pill by law. Maid, to thy master's bed, Thy mistress is o' th' brothel. Son of sixteen, Pluck the lined crutch from thy old limping sire, With it beat out his brains! Piety and fear, Religion to the gods, peace, justice, truth, Domestic awe, night-rest and neighbourhood, Instruction, manners, mysteries and trades, Degrees, observances, customs and laws, Decline to your confounding contraries, And let confusion live! Plagues incident to men, Your potent and infectious fevers heap On Athens, ripe for stroke! Thou cold sciatica, Cripple our senators, that their limbs may halt As lamely as their manners! Lust and liberty, Creep in the minds and marrows of our youth, That 'gainst the stream of virtue they may strive And drown themselves in riot! Itches, blains, Sow all th' Athenian bosoms, and their crop Be general leprosy! Breath infect breath, That their society, as their friendship, may Be merely poison! Nothing I'll bear from thee But nakedness, thou detestable town! Take thou that too, with multiplying bans! Timon will to the woods, where he shall find Th' unkindest beast more kinder than mankind. The gods confound-hear me, you good gods all!- Th' Athenians both within and out that wall, And grant, as Timon grows, his hate may grow To the whole race of mankind, high and low! Amen.

scenes.location: Athens. A room in Timon's house

dialogues.speaker: First Servant
dialogues.line: Hear you, Master Steward, where's our master? Are we undone, cast off, nothing remaining?

dialogues.speaker: Flavius
